## Barack Obama's Connection to "To Kill a Mockingbird"

President Obama commemorated the 50th Anniversary of "To Kill a Mockingbird"—a 1962 film adaptation of author Harper Lee's 1960 novel about racial inequality in the deep south—by hosting a screening in the Family Theater at the White House in April 2012. 

"Each one of us needs to try to heed the advice of a great character in American fiction, Atticus Finch," said President Obama during his farewell speech on Jan. 10. "'You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view. Until you climb into his skin and walk around in it.'"(no content)When I brought up the comparison with Badham, who met Obama at a 2012 White House screening of To Kill a Mockingbird, she burst out laughing. "And it's funny because having been with the president, I had the same thought when we were together. He's got that sense of humor. He puts people at ease as soon as he walks in the door." Mary Badham, who played Scout in the film, noted similarities between Obama and Gregory Peck's character Atticus Finch.

## Oprah Winfrey's Deep Connection to the Novel

Winfrey learned to read before the age of 3, and her favorite novel of all time is To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee.
